articles.title: AI teachers and cybernetics - what could the world look like in 2050?
articles.summary: We asked several experts to predict the technology we'll be using by 2050
articles.content:
AI teachers and cybernetics - what could the world look like in 2050?

6 hours ago Share Save Laura Cress Technology reporter Share Save

CBS Photo Archive The 2000 film Minority Report, set in 2054, imagined potential future technologies like controlling computers by making hand gestures

The last 25 years has seen some mind-bending technological changes. At the start of the century, most computers connected to the internet with noisy dial-up connections, Netflix was an online DVD rental company, and the vast majority of people hadn't even heard of a smartphone. Fast forward two and a half decades, and innovations in AI, robotics and much else besides are emerging at an incredible rate. So we decided to ask experts what the next 25 years could bring. Here are their predictions for the technology we'll be using by 2050 - and how it could reshape our lives.

Merging humans and machines

Science fiction set in the 2050s is full of examples of humans using technological enhancements to feel fitter, happier and more productive. In the 2000 hit game Deus Ex - set in 2052 - the player can inject themselves with tiny robots called "nanites". These microscopic robots manipulate matter on atomic levels, giving superhuman abilities such as enhanced speed and the ability to see in the dark.

Eidos In the video game Deus Ex, the protagonist - who enhances his abilities with augmentations - investigates a global conspiracy involving a terrorist group and secret societies

It sounds like something from the distant future, but nanotechnology - engineering at a scale of millionths of a millimetre - is already used in lots of everyday real-life tech. In fact, it is powering the way you are reading these very words right now - every smartphone or computer is run by a central chip made up of billions of tiny transistors - electrical components built on a nanoscale to speed up data processing. Professor Steven Bramwell at the London Centre for Nanotechnology told the BBC by 2050 we should expect the lines between machines, electronics and biology to be "significantly blurred". That means we could see nanotechnology implants by then - but more to "monitor your health or aid communication" rather than to appear invisible, as in Deus Ex. Medicine could also make common use of machines at a nanometre scale to "deliver drugs to exactly where they need to go", said Professor Bramwell. Cybernetics professor Kevin Warwick is equally interested in studying augmentations, going one step further than most. In 1998 he became the first human to have a microchip implanted into his nervous system, earning him the title "Captain Cyborg". Professor Warwick believes by 2050, advancements in cybernetics - the science studying the links between natural and mechanical systems - could lead to trailblazing treatments for diseases.

Kevin Warwick Professor Warwick has undertaken several pioneering experiments with the chip, including controlling a robot arm across the Atlantic Ocean using only his brain.

He predicts the use of "deep brain electronic stimulation" as a partial treatment for some conditions such as schizophrenia, rather than medicine. He adds it is likely we'll see more cybernetic enhancements of the kind he has already trialled himself, so that "your brain and body can be in different places". And what if we wanted to test out how the latest enhancement, or even new diet worked on our bodies, without any risks of experiencing the side effects? Professor Roger Highfield, director of the Science Museum Group believes "digital twins" - virtual versions of a physical object, updated using real time data - could become a regular feature in our lives. He imagines a world where each of us could have "thousands of simplified twins", using them to explore how "different medications or lifestyle changes affect your unique biology". In other words, we could preview our futures before we live them.

The next generation of AI

Many technology firms, including Google and IBM, are currently locked in a multi-billion dollar race to revolutionise how we push fields like AI even further - in the form of quantum computing. Quantum computers are machines which can do very complex calculations at incredibly fast speeds - for example, simulating molecular interactions to design new drugs faster. In January 2025, Jensen Huang - boss of the leading chip firm Nvidia - said he believed "very useful" quantum computing would come in 20 years. AI itself will undoubtedly continue to loom large in our society as we journey towards the half century mark. Futurist and author Tracey Follows, who helped write a government White Paper on UK education in 2050, believes learning will take place across "virtual and physical realities" using AI teachers which "adjust in real time". Rather than textbooks, she predicts children will use "immersive simulations". Meanwhile, education will be less standardised, with each child's individual DNA or biometric data studied to understand how they learn best.

Traffic-free roads and lunar bases

Bloomberg Waymo is a company developing autonomous driving technology

The writer Bill Douglass is well-versed in making compelling forecasts - in 2000 he won a $20,000 (£14,800) global futurist writing contest entitled "The World in 2050". While he still agrees one of his original predictions - pilotless planes - will come true by 2050, he believes we will first see more advances in driverless cars, making traffic congestion "largely a thing of the past". "Cars will drive so much closer to each other than they can now," he told the BBC. "And if one has to break, they all break. "On private toll roads for autonomous vehicles, there's no reason traffic can't go up to 100 miles an hour or so - you'll see mortality from traffic accidents plummet." Away from Earth, the space race will equally continue at speed, journalist and co-host of the Space Boffins podcast Sue Nelson told the BBC. She says in 25 years, it is likely there will be a liveable base on the Moon; and some industries could be almost entirely based in space. For example, she believes we may see pharmaceutical companies making the next generation of medicines in microgravity, i.e. on board an orbiting spacecraft. This is because, she says, crystals grown this way rather than on Earth, are "often larger and better quality".

Sci-fi meets science

articles.personality_title: Experts predict AI teachers, cybernetic health tools, and moon bases by 2050
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Over the past 25 years, technology has changed a lot, from slow internet and DVDs to smartphones and AI. Experts were asked to imagine what technology might look like 25 years from now, in 2050.

**What happened** – Scientists and futurists shared their ideas: tiny nanobots inside our bodies could help monitor health or deliver medicine directly where needed. Cybernetics, which links machines and humans, might treat diseases using brain implants. AI teachers could create lessons that fit each student’s unique way of learning using virtual reality. Self-driving cars might make traffic safer and faster. There could even be a liveable base on the Moon where medicines are made in space.

**Impact** – These predictions show how technology might improve health, education, and travel. For example, nanobots could help doctors treat illness more precisely, and AI teachers could help every child learn better by matching lessons to their needs. Driverless cars working together could reduce accidents and traffic jams. Making medicines in space could lead to better drugs because of unique conditions there.

**What's next step** – Over the coming decades, researchers and companies will work on building these technologies. Quantum computers might speed up drug discovery. More experiments with brain implants and AI in classrooms will test how well they work. Space agencies and businesses will prepare for living and working on the Moon.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By 2050, advanced technologies like AI education, health-monitoring nanobots, and space habitats could change how we live, learn, and stay healthy in everyday life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des experts prévoient des enseignants IA, des outils cybernétiques et des bases lunaires d’ici 2050
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au cours des 25 dernières années, la technologie a beaucoup changé, passant d’internet lent et de DVD aux smartphones et à l’IA. Des experts ont été invités à imaginer à quoi ressemblerait la technologie en 2050.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques et futuristes ont partagé leurs idées : de minuscules nanorobots dans notre corps pourraient surveiller la santé ou délivrer des médicaments précisément là où c’est nécessaire. La cybernétique, qui relie machines et humains, pourrait traiter des maladies grâce à des implants cérébraux. Les enseignants IA pourraient créer des cours adaptés à la façon unique d’apprendre de chaque élève en utilisant la réalité virtuelle. Les voitures autonomes pourraient rendre le trafic plus sûr et plus rapide. Il pourrait même y avoir une base habitable sur la Lune où l’on fabriquerait des médicaments dans l’espace.

**Impact** – Ces prédictions montrent comment la technologie pourrait améliorer la santé, l’éducation et les déplacements. Par exemple, les nanorobots pourraient aider les médecins à soigner les maladies plus précisément, et les enseignants IA pourraient aider chaque enfant à mieux apprendre en adaptant les cours à ses besoins. Les voitures autonomes travaillant ensemble pourraient réduire les accidents et les embouteillages. Fabriquer des médicaments dans l’espace pourrait permettre d’obtenir de meilleurs traitements grâce aux conditions uniques.

**Prochaine étape** – Au cours des prochaines décennies, chercheurs et entreprises vont développer ces technologies. Les ordinateurs quantiques pourraient accélérer la découverte de médicaments. Plus d’expériences avec des implants cérébraux et l’IA en classe testeront leur efficacité. Les agences spatiales et entreprises prépareront la vie et le travail sur la Lune.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – D’ici 2050, des technologies avancées comme l’éducation par IA, les nanorobots de santé et les habitats spatiaux pourraient transformer notre manière de vivre, d’apprendre et de rester en bonne santé au quotidien.
articles.personality_title_es: Expertos predicen profesores IA, herramientas cibernéticas y bases lunares para 2050
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En los últimos 25 años, la tecnología ha cambiado mucho, desde internet lento y DVDs hasta teléfonos inteligentes e inteligencia artificial (IA). Se pidió a expertos imaginar cómo sería la tecnología en 2050.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos y futuristas compartieron sus ideas: nanobots diminutos dentro de nuestro cuerpo podrían monitorear la salud o entregar medicinas justo donde se necesitan. La cibernética, que conecta máquinas y humanos, podría tratar enfermedades con implantes cerebrales. Los profesores de IA podrían crear lecciones que se adapten a la forma única en que aprende cada estudiante usando realidad virtual. Los coches autónomos podrían hacer el tráfico más seguro y rápido. Incluso podría haber una base habitable en la Luna donde se fabriquen medicinas en el espacio.

**Impacto** – Estas predicciones muestran cómo la tecnología podría mejorar la salud, la educación y el transporte. Por ejemplo, los nanobots podrían ayudar a los médicos a tratar enfermedades con más precisión, y los profesores de IA podrían ayudar a cada niño a aprender mejor al adaptar las lecciones a sus necesidades. Los coches autónomos trabajando juntos podrían reducir accidentes y atascos. Fabricar medicinas en el espacio podría producir mejores medicamentos debido a las condiciones especiales.

**Próximo paso** – En las próximas décadas, investigadores y empresas trabajarán para crear estas tecnologías. Las computadoras cuánticas podrían acelerar el descubrimiento de medicamentos. Se harán más pruebas con implantes cerebrales y IA en las aulas para ver qué tan bien funcionan. Las agencias espaciales y empresas prepararán la vida y el trabajo en la Luna.

**Resumen en una frase** – Para 2050, tecnologías avanzadas como la educación con IA, nanobots para la salud y hábitats espaciales podrían cambiar cómo vivimos, aprendemos y cuidamos nuestra salud cada día.

articles.title: New cat color unlocked: ’salty liquorice’ sheds light on feline genetics

articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Our Best of 2025 Education stories reflect a growing global commitment to reimagining how we learn, teach, and grow. These five highlights explore new models, inspiring individuals, and bold ideas that bring equity and creativity into classrooms and beyond.

In a surprising turn for feline genetics, scientists have officially identified a new cat coat color that defies traditional classifications. Named salmiak after the salty liquorice candy popular in Finland, this unique coat starts as black at the root and fades to white at the tip of each hair strand, giving cats a misty, monochrome appearance unlike anything seen before.

The coat was first spotted in 2007 and began attracting scientific attention in 2019 when a group of experts led by feline geneticist Heidi Anderson set out to understand its origin. After years of investigation, the team published their findings in the journal Animal Genetics, confirming that this striking coat is caused not by a known gene but by a newly discovered recessive mutation.

A colorful mystery unraveled

When it comes to cat colors, the basics are surprisingly simple: genetically, cats come in just two shades—black and orange. Every other coat color, from grey to cream to calico, is the result of the dilution, combination, or patterning of those two foundational colors.

So when cats began appearing with the distinct salt-and-pepper look of salmiak, researchers initially suspected a novel expression of the dilution gene, which typically mutes standard black and orange shades. But something didn’t add up.

The team tested known genetic variants that influence the dilution gene and found no connection. That’s when they decided to sequence the entire genome of two salmiak-coated cats—a deep dive that paid off.

“There was a huge chunk of sequence missing downstream from the KIT gene,” Anderson told New Scientist, referencing a gene already associated with white coat patterns in animals. In these cats, a nearby piece of DNA was simply missing, revealing a novel mutation that had never been documented before.

Rare and recessive, but admired

After testing 181 cats, the researchers confirmed that this missing sequence is the cause of the salmiak coat. Because the mutation is recessive, both parent cats must carry the gene for it to appear in their offspring, which helps explain why the pattern is so rare.

Despite its rarity, the color has drawn admiration from cat lovers and researchers alike. “These coats have aroused a lot of admiration for years,” Anderson said. “It’s really exciting that we now have some genetic explanation for it.”

More than just pretty fur

The discovery not only deepens our understanding of feline genetics but could also play a role in responsible breeding practices. As Anderson states, solving the salmiak puzzle “enriches our understanding of feline coat color genetics” and could help preserve this unique trait in future generations.

While this elegant, mist-tipped coat may still be a rare sight, researchers and breeders alike hope it will become a lasting feature in the colorful world of cat genetics.

Source study: Animal Genetics—A new Finnish flavor of feline coat coloration, “salmiak,” is associated with a 95-kb deletion downstream of the KIT gene

articles.personality_title: Scientists discover new cat coat color called 'salty liquorice'
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Cats usually have coat colors based on just two main colors: black and orange. Other colors come from mixing or changing these basics. But recently, scientists found a new cat color that did not fit these rules.

**What happened** – A group of scientists led by feline geneticist Heidi Anderson studied a new cat coat color named salmiak, inspired by a salty liquorice candy in Finland. This color looks like black at the roots of the fur fading to white at the tips, giving cats a misty, grey look. The team found that this unique color comes from a rare genetic change that had never been seen before. They discovered a missing piece of DNA near an important gene called KIT, which affects coat colors.

**Impact** – This is the first time this kind of mutation has been found in cats, helping us understand more about how cat colors work. Because the change is recessive, cats need two parents with the gene to show this color, which explains why it is very rare. Knowing about this gene can help breeders keep this special coat color alive and healthy in future cats.

**What's next step** – Researchers and cat breeders will use this new genetic knowledge to study more cats with this coat and possibly encourage responsible breeding to preserve the salmiak color. This discovery may also help scientists learn more about how genes control animal appearances.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have identified a rare, new cat coat color called salmiak caused by a unique genetic mutation, opening new paths in feline genetics and breeding.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent une nouvelle couleur de pelage de chat appelée « réglisse salée »
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les chats ont généralement deux couleurs principales : noir et orange. Les autres couleurs viennent de mélanges ou de modifications de ces bases. Mais récemment, des scientifiques ont trouvé une nouvelle couleur de pelage qui ne correspondait pas à ces règles.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par la généticienne féline Heidi Anderson a étudié une nouvelle couleur de pelage appelée salmiak, inspirée d’un bonbon finlandais à la réglisse salée. Cette couleur commence noir à la racine du poil et devient blanche au bout, donnant un aspect gris brumeux. L’équipe a découvert que cette couleur vient d’un changement génétique rare et jamais vu auparavant : une partie manquante d’ADN près du gène KIT, qui influence les couleurs du pelage.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’une telle mutation est trouvée chez les chats, ce qui aide à mieux comprendre comment fonctionnent les couleurs chez eux. Cette mutation est récessive, ce qui signifie qu’un chat doit avoir deux parents porteurs pour avoir cette couleur, expliquant sa rareté. Cette découverte peut aider les éleveurs à préserver cette couleur unique.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs et éleveurs utiliseront ces nouvelles connaissances pour étudier plus de chats avec cette couleur et encourager l’élevage responsable du salmiak. Cette découverte pourrait aussi aider à mieux comprendre comment les gènes contrôlent l’apparence des animaux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont identifié une couleur de pelage rare appelée salmiak, causée par une mutation génétique unique, ouvrant de nouvelles voies en génétique féline et en élevage.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren un nuevo color de pelaje de gato llamado ‘regaliz salado’
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los gatos generalmente tienen dos colores principales: negro y naranja. Otros colores surgen de mezclar o alterar estos colores básicos. Pero recientemente, los científicos encontraron un nuevo color de pelaje que no encajaba en estas reglas.

**Qué pasó** – Un grupo de científicos liderado por la genetista felina Heidi Anderson estudió un nuevo color de pelaje llamado salmiak, inspirado en un dulce finlandés de regaliz salado. Este color comienza negro en la raíz del pelo y se vuelve blanco en la punta, dando un aspecto gris brumoso. El equipo descubrió que este color único viene de un cambio genético raro y nunca antes visto: una pieza de ADN faltante cerca del gen KIT, que afecta los colores del pelaje.

**Impacto** – Esta es la primera vez que se encuentra este tipo de mutación en gatos, lo que ayuda a entender mejor cómo funcionan los colores en ellos. La mutación es recesiva, lo que significa que un gato necesita dos padres con el gen para mostrar este color, explicando por qué es tan raro. Conocer este gen puede ayudar a los criadores a mantener este color especial.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores y criadores usarán este nuevo conocimiento genético para estudiar más gatos con este pelaje y posiblemente fomentar la cría responsable para conservar el color salmiak. Este descubrimiento también podría ayudar a aprender más sobre cómo los genes controlan la apariencia de los animales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Científicos identificaron un color de pelaje raro llamado salmiak causado por una mutación genética única, abriendo nuevas vías en la genética y cría de gatos.
